2. Entry within the confines of the camp shall be forbidden to any person except detainees and the officer in charge or his assistants and those persons who have received special permission from the officer in charge.
3. (1) Detainees when not at work outside the camp shall remain within the confines of the camp.
(2) Absence from the camp without permission shall be deemed to be escape from lawful custody.

4. Subject to any general or specific instructions from the Commissioner of Prisons, the nature of the work on which detainees are to be employed shall be at the discretion of the officer in charge of the detention camp.

6. (1) Detainees may wear their own clothes throughout their period of detention, provided they are suitable; otherwise they may be provided with clothes.
(2) Bedding shall be supplied to detainees.
7. (1) Detainees must display whilst undergoing detention the identity disc which will be issued to them on admission to the detention camp.
(2) Loss of the identity disc may be treated as an offence.
8. Detainees may associate together throughout the period of their detention, but may be required to maintain silence while at work or after such time at night as is ordered by the officer in charge.
9. Detainees may receive and send out letters to such number as is in the case of each detainee ordered by the officer in charge.
10. Detainees may, by permission of the officer in charge, receive special visits from their legal advisers or near relations.

11. In the event of any offence against discipline on the part of a detainee, such as refusal to work, idleness at work, quarrelling with other detainees, or any neglect or disobedience of orders, the offender shall be taken before the prescribed authority to be dealt with under section 12 of the Act.
12. No intoxicating liquor or African intoxicating liquor or tobacco may be given to a detainee except on the written authority to the medical officer.
13. The rules concerning censorship of prisoner's letters made under the Prisons Act shall apply, mutatis mutandis, to detainees.
14. The prescribed authority shall be the person for the time being holding the position of officer in charge.

section.heading: SECTION THE DETENTION CAMPS (TREATMENT IN HOSPITAL) RULES

xhtml:p.xhtml:b: THE DETENTION CAMPS (TREATMENT IN HOSPITAL) RULES

xhtml:td.xhtml:p: 1. These Rules may be cited as the Detention Camps (Treatment in Hospital) Rules

2. (1) If any detainee appears to be of unsound mind in any detention camp, the officer in charge of the detention camp shall forthwith report to a medical officer, and such medical officer shall visit and inquire into the state of mind of such detainee.

(2) If the medical officer signs a certificate with respect to such detainee according to the form in the Schedule to these Rules, the officer in charge shall forward a copy of such certificate to the Minister, and it shall be lawful for the Minister, by order in writing under his hand directed to the officer in charge of such detention camp, to order that such detainee be forthwith removed to any fit place for the custody and treatment of lunatics, which may from time to time be appointed by the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry for that purpose either within any prison or elsewhere.

(3) Any detainee so removed shall remain in such place until it is certified by a medical officer that such detainee has become of sound mind, whereupon he shall by order of the Minister be redelivered into the custody of the officer in charge of such detention camp if still liable to be detained therein, and if not so liable released.

3. (1) In case of any serious illness of a detainee detained in a detention camp in which there is not suitable accommodation for such detainee, any magistrate may, on the certificate of a medical officer, make an order for his removal to a Government hospital.
(2) In case of emergency, such removal may be made by an officer in charge of the detention camp without complying with the provisions of paragraph (1) of this rule.
4. (1) So long as any detainee who has been removed to any hospital under rule 3 of these Rules remains therein, he shall be deemed to be in lawful custody.

(2) The medical officer of the hospital shall, at the end of every month, transmit to the officer in charge of the detention camp a certificate signed by him that it is in his opinion necessary that such detainee should remain in the hospital.

5. So soon as, in the opinion of the medical officer of the hospital, it is no longer necessary for a detainee who has been removed to the hospital to remain therein, he shall transmit to the officer in charge of the detention camp a certificate stating that such necessity has ceased, and thereupon the officer in charge of the detention camp shall forthwith cause such detainee to be brought to the detention camp if he is still liable to be detained therein.

6. Every precaution shall be taken by the medical officers and other officers of a hospital to prevent the escape of any detainee who may at any time be under treatment therein, and it shall be lawful for the said officers to take such measures for preventing the escape of any such detainee as are necessary:
Provided that nothing in this rule contained shall confer any authority to do any act which in the opinion of the medical officer is likely to be prejudicial to the health of such detainee.

3. Any overseer who -
(i) uses traitorous or disloyal words regarding the President; or
(ii) strikes or uses or offers any violence against his superior officer, or uses threatening or insubordinate language to his superior officer; or
(iii) willfully disobeys any lawful command; or
(iv) is drunk, or drinks intoxicants while actually on duty; or
(v) absents himself without leave; or
(vi) sleeps on his post, or leaves it before being regularly relieved except in fresh pursuit of any offender whom he ought to apprehend; or
(vii) being under arrest or confinement, leaves or escapes from his arrest or confinement before he is set at liberty by proper authority; or
(viii) neglects or refuses to assist in the apprehension of any overseer or detainee whom it is his duty to arrest; or
(ix) allows any detainee to escape who is committed to his charge or whom it is his duty to keep or guard; or
(x) offers unwarrantable personal violence to any person in his custody; or
(xi) is guilty of cowardice; or
(xii) without cause fails to appear at any parade appointed by his superior officer; or
(xiii) pawns, sells, loses by neglect, makes away with or willfully spoils his arms, accoutrements, clothing or necessaries or any medal or decoration granted to him for service or good conduct; or

(xiv) steals any money or goods the property of any overseer or detainee, or steals or embezzles any Government money or goods, or receives any such money or goods, knowing them to have been stolen or embezzled from any overseer or detainee of the Government; or
(xv) commits any act of plunder or wanton destruction of property; or
(xvi) solicits or accepts a gratuity; or
(xvii) is slovenly, inattentive, in civil or quarrelsome; or
(xviii) without due authority discloses or conveys any information concerning any investigation or departmental matter; or
(xix) malingers or feigns or produces any disease or infirmity; or

(xx) is wilfully guilty of misconduct, or wilfully disobeys, whether in hospital or otherwise, any orders by means of which misconduct or disobedience he produces or aggravate disease or infirmity or delays its cure; or
(xxi) incurs debt; or
(xxii) without proper authority exacts from any person carriage, porterage or provisions; or
(xxiii) resists an escort whose duty is to apprehend him or to have him in charge; or
(xxiv) breaks out of lines, camp or quarters; or
(xxv) makes any false statement on becoming an overseer; or
(xxvi) refuses or by culpable neglect omits to make or send a report or return which it is his duty to make or send; or
(xxvii) makes a false accusation against any overseer or detainee knowing such accusation to be false; or
(xxviii) in making a complaint, where he thinks himself wronged knowingly makes any false statement affecting the character of any overseer or knowingly and wilfully suppresses any material facts; or
(xxix) engages without authority in any employment other than his duty as an overseer; or
(xxx) is guilty of any other act, conduct, disorder or neglect to the prejudice of good order and discipline shall be deemed to have committed an offence against discipline:
Provided that nothing in this rule shall be construed to exempt any overseer from being proceeded against for any offence by the ordinary course of law.

section.heading: SECTION 5 Power to sentence to detention.

foreign.xhtml:div:
5.(1) When a person is convicted of any offence and the court, after taking into consideration the apparent age, antecedents, character and state of health of the person accused and all the circumstances and, is of opinion that the offence would be adequately punished by a fine or a sentence of imprisonment not exceeding six months, the court may instead of awarding a sentence of a fine or imprisonment award a sentence of detention in a detention camp, and the prisoner shall thereupon be detained in a detention camp.
(2) A sentence of detention shall in no case exceed the period of imprisonment to which the prisoner could have been sentenced if this Act had not been enacted.
(3) Where any Act provides that an offence is punishable by fine only or by fine and imprisonment in default of payment of such fine, the court may order that in default of payment the prisoner undergo a sentence of detention in lieu of imprisonment.

section.heading: SECTION 6 High Court may alter imprisonment to detention or vice versa.

foreign.xhtml:div: 6.Where a sentence of fine or imprisonment or detention comes before the High Court on appeal or in exercise of its powers of revision or confirmation, the High Court may, after taking into consideration the apparent age, antecedents, character or state of health of the prisoner and all the circumstances of the case, alter any sentence of fine or imprisonment to a sentence of detention or a sentence of detention to a sentence of fine or imprisonment.

section.heading: SECTION 7 Revising officer of African court may alter imprisonment to detention or vice versa.

foreign.xhtml:div: 7. Where a sentence of fine or imprisonment or detention is awarded by an African court, an officer having power to revise the proceedings of the court may, after taking into consideration the apparent age, antecedents, character and state of health of the prisoner and all the circumstances of the case, alter any sentence of fine or imprisonment to a sentence of detention or a sentence of detention to a sentence of fine or imprisonment.

8. No person shall be sentenced to detention for a period exceeding six months in all, and no sentence of detention shall be passed on any person who is proved to have previously undergone more than one term of imprisonment.

9.(1) Every detainee under sentence of detention for more than one month may earn remission of one third of his sentence by satisfactory industry and good conduct:
Provided that no such remission may be earned so as to reduce the period of detention to a period less than one month.
(2) On the recommendation of the Commissioner of Prisons, the Minister may grant such further remission as he shall determine, on special grounds, such as exceptional merit or permanent ill-health.
(3) For the purpose of giving effect to the provisions of subsection (1) of this section, each detainee, on admission shall be credited with the full amount of remission he could earn, and shall forfeit such portion of such remission as a
punishment for idleness, lack of industry or any other offence against discipline, as the Commissioner of Prisons or the officer in charge of the detention camp shall determine:
Provided that the Commissioner may restore any forfeited remission in whole or in part.
10.A detainee while in a detention camp shall be kept to labour, but shall not receive pay for any work which he may perform.

section.heading: SECTION 11 Removal from one camp to another.

foreign.xhtml:div: 11.The prescribed authority may at any time by order remove a detainee from one detention camp to another.

12. A detainee convicted by the prescribed authority of any offence against discipline as provided for by this Act or by any rules made thereunder may be committed to prison to undergo the remainder of his sentence.

section.heading: SECTION 12A Detainee may serve unexpired period of detention in prison.

foreign.xhtml:div: 12A. A detainee who is convicted by any court for any offence committed during the period of his detention and sentenced to a term of imprisonment for such offence, or who is convicted by any court for the offence of escape from lawful custody committed during the period of his detention, shall serve the unexpired period of his detention in a prison in addition to any other sentence passed on him in respect of such offence or such escape.

section.heading: SECTION 13 Identity card and identity disc.

foreign.xhtml:div:
13.(1) A detainee on admission shall hand his identity card or registration certificate to the officer in charge of the detention camp and shall be issued with an identity disc to be worn during his term of detention.
(2) On his release from detention a detainee shall surrender the identity disc to the officer in charge and receive back his identity card or registration certificate.

section.heading: SECTION 14 Detainees deemed to be in lawful custody.

foreign.xhtml:div: 14. A detainee while serving a sentence of detention shall be deemed to be lawfully in custody.
